content: Why is there no integer for a number of inputs?

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Everything looks fine. Not too hard, not too easy :)
Test and validator cases should have the number of lines of input. Otherwise you are counting causing errors as part of the expected behavior.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Funny clash of code, I like the idea of the acrostic.

I must agree that having the stub code getting only one line is unusual in this kind of clash, but not unsolvable given the input explanation.
A little confusing, but reverse is all about "getting it"
I'd like to approve it but I'm not competent to check the "stub works in all languages" (tested some but not all)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a nice reverse clash, but i could do all test cases with a completely different code...
The default stub code should loop over the input, especially since it is for reverse mode. The default stub code currently only takes in one line.
hey davilla i think it is nice
You should maybe give the number of lines

Thanks for the comment. I considered that, but it seems solvable without. It's so simple once you get it, this just becomes a mini-challenge.

In that light, do you hold the same opinion? Have you tried solving it as is, and without any advanced trickery in the vein of open(0), to see if it's doable in the most straightjacketed language?
Thank you!  It was inspired by a puzzle called Acrostic from AcornBob.

It's currently not possible to write a loop in the stub without giving it the exact number of lines, and I don't want to do that if I can avoid it, to make determining the end of the input part of the puzzle. I wish there were a way to set up a generic loop.
You mean checking for end of input? Yes that's acceptable too (nicer actually), but not everyone knows it's possible, hence the other option.

The current stub does not cause any errors. The following python code actually passes the first test case:

line = input()
print("fat cat")

Of course, all input will have to be read for the solution to pass the validators. I wish I could write a smarter stub that at least sets up a loop, but the framework won't allow it. Determining the end of the input is meant to be part of the puzzle.
Because it's solvable and slightly more challenging without. That's part of the design of the puzzle.
Personally I dislike hiding the rest of the input, you are shifting the challenge onto the setup rather than the actual puzzle.

I understand how to solve it, but it is very weird to me. I have no definitive opinion on it.
BUT if you want to keep it like this, change some test cases to have more "!" (maybe half of them), and have at least one in the validators. The test cases and validators should have exactly the same punctuation, so at the very least, put a bang "!" on validator 3.
OK, I've taken some further liberties to end 2 of each with an exclamation point, the ones that seemed most emphatic, instead of just the one test.
